MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE

FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1974 TO 31ST MARCH, 1975



    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee of Supply [5th Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head LA --

    Mr Lee Yiok Seng (Bukit Panjang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head LA be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AA 1004*. (*The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs Cheong Yuen Chee and Ong Teng Cheong.)

    Recently the Ministry of National Development announced that 45 acres of land at Bah Soon Pah Road would be used for commercial pig farming, and that the land would be subdivided into eight lots of about five acres each for

Column: 632

development by public application. This is a new project for pig farming in Singapore as we are encouraging the development of pig farming into a commercial enterprise. I have gone through the terms and conditions attached to the application form. It is clearly stated that the applicant should put up the building and all facilities including multi-storey piggeries on the 5-acre land and maintain a production of 1,000 porkers per acre per annum. Therefore, this project must involve at least a capital of $« million or even more. As such a big capital is required. I am sure that even if pig farmers in Singapore have the desire and the practical experience of participating in this project, they have very little chance of doing so because they are individual smallholders without big capital. I am very disappointed over the fact that the Minister does not take into consideration the present condition of pig farmers in

Column: 633

Singapore, whereby provision could be made to give them a chance to participate in this project. Therefore, I sincerely urge the Minister to consider if the Government can set aside a portion of this land for the small pig farmers? Moreover, I propose that Government be responsible for the building of multi-storey piggeries and all the other necessary facilities, including pig pens. This piggery can then be subdivided into smaller units which will be suitable for the small pig farmers. Such pig farming units can be rented out to the pig farmers or sold to them on an instalment basis. This will enable the pig farmers to benefit from the project, and at the same time help them to develop their pig rearing in a far better environment. Sir, if this can be done 1 am sure the farmers will deeply appreciate it.

    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Sir, the announcement in increases in prices for Housing Board fiats made by the Minister on 30th November last year came as a stunning blow to many prospective flat owners. With the current inflation, the increase in prices is an additional burden to the ordinary wage earners. Sir, you will appreciate that before one decides to apply for the purchase of a Housing Board flat, he will have to ascertain whether the price of the flat and the instalment payments allowed fit in with his financial resources. He will then decide on either a three-, four- or five-room flat and the period of repayment, whether it is in 10, 15, or 20 years. Many applicants who have applied for flats two or three years ago have based their decision on these assumptions. But the increase of more than 50 per cent in prices will entail a corresponding increase in the monthly instalment payment. Such a move by the Housing Board has indeed caused a major upset in the financial circumstances of these prospective flat owners.

    Sir, I am not in disagreement with the reasons given by the Minister but I am questioning the manner in which this considerable increase in prices is being imposed. In his statement the Minister stated that the cost of providing public

Column: 634

housing has risen considerably. These are facts that cannot be disputed. But why cannot the increase in prices be spread over a period of, say, eight years, thereby gradually increasing the burden rather than a sudden blow. By doing so, the price of a three-room flat will only be increased at the rate of $500 each year. Moreover, such a scheme will apply to a lesser number of applicants at any one time. It will be gradual. Probably the Minister feared that the private property developers will take advantage of this and use this as an excuse for raising the prices of their properties. Sir, prices of properties in the private sector have been increasing by leaps and bounds over the last eight years, which is several hundred per cent more.

    I would also like to touch on another problem faced by applicants for Housing Board flats. Many applicants have been waiting for their flats for as long as three years. Since the Board is unable to meet the needs of these applicants many have resorted to unauthorised occupation of Housing Board flats rented from the flat owners or tenants. Unfortunately, the Housing Board took a dim view of these happenings, and eviction notices were served on the owners or tenants. Notices read like this:

    `You are hereby requested to evict so-and-so and resume proper occupation of your flat, failing which legal action will be served to recover the said property.'

Sir, where can these people go to for alternative accommodation, if the Housing Board itself is unable to provide them with alternative accommodation because of the length of time in the construction of flats. They are all ordinary wage earners and they are in no position to find cheap alternative accommodation in the private sector unless they want to live in shacks in squatter areas. I am not encouraging or condoning breaches of Housing Board regulations, but in situations of this nature sympathetic consideration should be given in order to alleviate the plight of these applicants for Housing Board flats. May I, therefore, suggest that unauthorised occupiers of Housing Board flats, who have registered for the

Column: 635

purchase or rental of Housing Board flats, be permitted on compassionate grounds to stay in such flats until they have been allocated flats.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong (Kim Keat): Sir, you may recall the announcement that was made in September last year regarding the restriction on the purchase of residential properties in the Republic. It stated that non-citizens, permanent residents, and companies incorporated in Singapore or abroad must obtain permission from the Government to buy houses. This announcement, though rather belatedly, was welcomed as it is intended to curb speculation in residential properties with a view to assisting our middle income group of citizens, who are not eligible at the present moment to purchase HDB flats, to own private houses as part of the Government's overall home ownership policy.

    But since the announcement in last September, there was a complete silence on the subject. Some of the permanent residents and non-citizens who wish to buy houses genuinely for their own use, hoping to make their home in the Republic, are at a loss as to where their applications should be submitted, or how to go about obtaining the necessary permission. Some of them have tried, I believe, and they have been going around from one department to another. Some of them are in our civil service and industry and other services. Many of them are making a useful contribution to the progress and prosperity of this country. There is no doubt that we wish them well and look forward to their continued contributions and service. Therefore, I will be pleased if the Minister could kindly inform the House as to when will he introduce legislation relating to this announcement last September to regulate the purchase of local residential property. And will the Minister also indicate the reasons for the delay in enacting this piece of legislation, and whether the delay is a deliberate measure?

    While I am still on the subject of home ownership, I wonder if the

Column: 636

Minister could elaborate on a recent announcement that the Government will be building houses for our middle-class citizens. Would he inform the House as to who will be responsible for the project? Where and when will this middle-class housing estate be constructed? How many units will be built annually? What will be the terms of sale and whether there will be any income limits imposed on the purchase of these houses? I am sure that not only members of the middle-income public are thrilled by the announcement, but also some Members of this House are just as anxious to hear more about this scheme.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong): Sir, I rise in support of my colleague, the Member for Bukit Panjang. Sir, though we cannot deny the commendable job done by the Primary Production Department on agriculture over the decade, we must admit that sometimes it does make silly decisions. Although we are not discussing the merits and demerits of the Department at this juncture, I cannot but point Out to the Minister one or two mistakes made by the Department recently. One mistake, which appeared somewhat shameful on the part of the Government, was that sometime ago the Primary Production Department ordered the feedstuff merchants to decrease the price of feedstuff. However, later the merchants not only ignored the order but also jacked up the price further. Surely the Department could have studied the supply and demand of feedstuff before placing an order, and then the order could be made firm and effective.

2.45 p.m.

    Another mistake was the decision to lease out the plot of land, as mentioned by the Member for Bukit Panjang, only to big-time farmers for the purpose of pig rearing. This is another evidence that the Primary Production Department is in favour of big-time farmers only. Ordinary farmers, I believe, are frightened by the rules and regulations in respect of this proposed pig farm. In the first instance, I think it is basically wrong to look after the big-time farmers only, for this is in violation of the fundamental

Column: 637

principles of democratic socialism which our Party advocates. It is the small-time farmers that we should look after.

    Sir, we all know that land is scarce in Singapore and we have to make use of air space to develop agriculture. Surely the Government can build standard multi-storey pigsties with infrastructure provided and let them out to our small-time farmers to enable them to make a living out of pig rearing. I think this is more workable and beneficial to our farming community as a whole. I will, therefore, urge the Minister concerned to give serious consideration to this proposal.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to touch on a very small point on the Government's policy on land acquisition. The Government policy has caused dissatisfaction among those property owners who have been affected by it because they felt that the compensation was not only inadequate but also unfair as the offer of compensation was made to them nearly four years after they were informed of the acquisition.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has started acquiring houses for urban renewal in my constituency since 1969, and the owners were asked to submit claims for compensation to the Commissioner of Lands. In compliance with the notice, all affected house owners submitted claims for compensation through their certified valuers in 1970. But after that, nothing was heard from the Commissioner of Lands. However, in 1974, four years after the submission of claims, the Commissioner of Lands has just made up his mind to announce his offer of compensation to the people concerned. Sir, you will agree with me that there is a world of difference in land prices as well as the purchasing power of money between 1970 and 1974. There is no need for me to illustrate or elaborate on this. They felt that the Commissioner had taken unfair advantage by delaying the matter for four

Column: 638

years, as the claims for compensation had been forwarded to the Commissioner since 1970. Why was it necessary to take four years to pay the compensation? Besides this unnecessary delay, the compensation offered by the Commissioner of Lands was only half of what they claimed four years ago. No doubt, there is provision for appeal if they feel that the compensation is inadequate. But let us be frank about it. How many people would like to go to court and appeal against the Government? Going to court and fighting a case against the Government is one thing, there is also the legal expenses, the time spent in court, and the inconvenience caused.

    In view of this, Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister: is four years the usual length of time that the Commissioner of Lands needs to determine the offer of compensation for acquisition of houses?

    Mr L. P. Rodrigo (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have an amendment to a subhead* relating to Loans to the Housing and Development Board, but I observe that the Member for Kim Keat has raised the matter on which I intended to say a few words. With your leave, Sir, may I raise my views at this stage?
* The amendment, standing in the names of Messrs N. Govindasamy and L.P. Rodrigo, reads as follows:

    (6) That the sum to be allocated for Head LG be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AA 3008.


    The Chairman: Yes.

    Mr Rodrigo: Sir, I appreciate the soundness of Government policy to urgently meet the housing needs of the lower income group. The fact of owning a home or staying in one at a reasonable rent is satisfaction of a basic physical and social need of the people and the achievement of a sense of security. This is a basic need of the middle income group as much as it is a basic need of the lower income group. Where this need could be satisfied by their own efforts a few years ago (that is, the people in the middle income group), the dramatic rise in the value of houses in the private sector has removed hopes of their realising this need.

Column: 639



    The prevailing restriction, Sir, on the sale of private property to non-citizens was enforced in September last year to lower the steep rise in property values, so that home ownership may be spread among the different categories of workers in our society. The restriction has had a dampening effect and property values have been said to fall by 15 to 25 per cent of values in August last year. However, prospect of a further significant decline in property values does not appear to be real in view of the steep rise in prices and costs of building materials, services and labour. The present property values seem already grounded upon real cost of materials and construction and appear unlikely to fall further significantly. This notwithstanding, the middle income group generally cannot afford the prices of houses in the private sector today, as these prices remain beyond their financial resources.

    The situation makes it important for the Government to start programming for ownership of HDB homes by the middle income group. The middle income group comprises professionals, administrators, and executives both in the public and private sectors upon whom, as the Government has admitted last year, the security and progress of Singapore depends. The middle income group would be assisted in some measure towards buying a home from the private sector if a portion of their savings in the Central Provident Fund could be used by them for this purpose. However, this suggestion was turned down by the Minister of State for Labour a few days ago in the debate on the Estimates for his Ministry. As long as all our workers can find in the meaning of hard work a practical realisation of their basic aspirations relating to true necessities and sound luxuries, our nation will continue, I think, to survive and prosper by the loyalty, skill and dedication of the middle income group workers.

    I hope the Minister will be able to state a favourable answer to me on this issue as much as to the hon. Member opposite and which answer, I am sure

Column: 640

and agree with him, is very much awaited by members of the middle income group.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I agree with the Members for Bukit Panjang and Jurong when they said that the Primary Production Department should build small pig farms for letting out to small scale farmers so as to enable them to carry out pig farming. There are reasons for such a move.

    Firstly, this will help small farmers to alleviate their economic difficulties. At present, pig farmers in the rural areas, for example, Sembawang and Jurong, Bukit Panjang, and Nee Soon, are faced with the same difficulties. In order to comply with the regulations of the Ministry of the Environment, in other words they should not pollute the water resources, they must construct a drain round the pig farms to ensure that there is proper drainage of the filthy water. But it costs a few thousand dollars to build such a sewage system. This is quite beyond the means of the small farmers.

    Secondly, the building of pig farms will increase pig production. We know that because of the high cost of animal feed, small farmers were not able to carry on with pig farming, and hence there was a shortage in the supply of pigs. The result was that pig prices went up by 300 per cent from $50 to $220 per picul. This will increase the burden on the consumers. So long as the Primary Production Department could let out the pig farms at low rentals to the small farmers, and buy animal feed in bulk and sell it to the farmers there will be a reduction in prices of animal feed. Thus, there will be a balance between the supply and demand of pigs to bring down prices of pork.

    Thirdly, to prevent pollution in the farming areas where there are modern pig farms and facilities, the pig farmers can be grouped together in a collective farm so that the problem of pollution will not arise.

    Fourthly, the Member for Jurong said that in drafting such a project, the Primary Production Department seems

Column: 641

to look after the interests of the big farmers because they are able to put in $1 million or $2 million capital, but for the small farmers even $10,000 is quite beyond their means. Sir, letting out such pig farms to the small farmers will get rid of the monopoly of the big farmers so that more and more pig farmers can take part in pig farming.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Minister could accept such suggestions, namely, that the Primary Production Department builds pig farms and then sell or rent them out to farmers, I believe the small farmers in the rural areas will be grateful.

    The Chairman: Since the Member for Serangoon Gardens has touched on Head LG subhead AA 3008, would the Member for Telok Blangah like to join in too?

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Certainly, Sir, if it will help. But I am really going to touch on a slightly different aspect of the problem altogether.

3.00 p.m.

    The Chairman: I am sure the Minister does not mind.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Very well, Sir,I have also given notice of amendments* to Head LG, subheads AA 2730 (item a), 3006 and 3008? Since the subject matter that I am going to discuss on all these subheads are related, I am wondering if I may, with your permission, Sir, range my discussion on all these three sub-heads simultaneously?

    The Chairman: Yes.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: I am grateful to you, Sir, and to the Hon. Minister

Column: 642

who has helped me solve a number of very knotty problems connected with the resettlement in my constituency.

    Sir, in addition to $506 million to be given as a loan to the Housing and Development Board under subhead AA 3008 and the appropriation of $10,552,000 to the Resettlement Department under subhead AA 3006, $30 million is to be given as a contribution under subhead AA 2730 to the Housing and Development Board for the financial year 1974. This totals up to $546,552,000. Sir, I am sure that doubling this appropriation would not even save the Housing and Development Board from the difficulty that it is facing in building the required number of housing units for our needs. Although the Housing and Development Board has been accorded world-wide acclaim for its achievements, it has not been able to satisfy our needs, the local needs. I believe it is not because we do not have the means to build more flats than at present but because the planning and programming of our housing requirements have gone haywire. Perhaps, the Minister being an amiable man has allowed himself to give in too easily to pressures by other Ministries and the statutory boards. As it is, the people affected by resettlement, although eligible for priority, have to wait for years before they are offered alternative accommodation. There are other categories of persons who are also eligible for priority accommodation. The latest addition to the priority list is ex-national servicemen. If we go on adding to this list of priority cases, then the day will come when normal applicants for Housing Board flats may have to wait a decade before they are allocated flats.

Column: 643

Sir, if the Minister is not careful, one of these days, the Minister for Health, who is not here now, is going to ask for priority for people who undergo voluntary sterilization. As it is, we have now two queues - one for persons with priority and the other for persons without any priority.

    Let me explain what I mean by bad planning and inadequate programming. I can best illustrate this by quoting examples from my own constituency. By the end of 1971, part of Pulau Brani was to be used by MINDEF and the other part was appropriated for PSA. A survey was made and residents were told that they had to move out, but no Housing Board flats were set aside nor planned for orderly resettlement. They had been asked to register for areas of their choice. Many of them wanted flats in Telok Blangah, but upon registration when they requested that they be registered for flats in Telok Blangah, they were told that they would have to register for Henderson area which had apparently been set aside for them. However, when the Henderson flats were balloted, only a handful of them were allotted flats there. Again, in 1972 a few households were allocated flats far away from Telok Blangah, resulting in undue hardship to the persons affected. It took almost two years to resettle about half the households from Pulau Brani. Meanwhile, the school on the island was closed, quite rightly, as the student population had decreased and the remaining islanders found themselves practically marooned on the island as the sampan-ferrying facilities were disrupted. Sir, to-date almost 2« years after being informed that they would be resettled, a large number of households are still on the island without any basic communal or social service such as schools. Moreover, the houses on the island, which are not brick and mortar houses but built on stilts with planks and attap or zinc roofing, are in a serious state of disrepair. They need constant repair and maintenance. Once indication was given that they would be resettled soon, neither the chief tenants nor the

Column: 644

house-owners were prepared to incur additional expenses on repairs. Partially abandoned huts also pose many health and fire hazards. This is what I mean by improper planning and programming before urban renewal is undertaken.

    Sir, resettlement is not a pleasant business though it is sometimes necessary. Let me liken resettlement to surgery for the removal of a cancerous growth with which you are very familiar. Sir, when a surgeon needs to perform a surgical operation, he will have all his instruments ready, the theatre prepared, a ready bed in the ward, and assurance of an adequate supply of blood made available, before even deciding to wheel the patient into the theatre. And during surgery, he will use a sharp scalpel and make a firm deft one-stroke incision. He does not go about it using an old razor blade, nor after having gone halfway through the operation look for a hospital bed or look for a supply of blood when the patient begins to bleed. This is what the Housing and Development Board is doing today.

    The Chairman: After such a gory description of resettlement, perhaps the Minister would like to reply!

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Sir, may I first deal with the question of commercial pig farming which has been referred to by three Members of Parliament? First, the Member for Bukit Panjang has given some details about the proposals, which were quite right. There are eight 5-acre lots of land located off Bah Soon Pah Road which were recently offered for commercial pig farming. Members may be interested to know that of the lots offered there have been seven tenders, some wanting more than one lot. The whole object of this exercise, which is a pilot scheme, is to increase the supply of pigs for the market. The Members have suggested that the Government should build these multi-storey structures and rent them out to the smaller farmers. The Member for Sembawang went further to say that the Primary Production Department should buy the feed in bulk and sell them to the farmers. Next, he will suggest that the

Column: 645

Primary Production Department should rear the pigs for them! I think all these three Members know, if they are active in their constituencies, that the work done by the Primary Production Department over the years has been to help small farmers. I do not propose to go into the details. But to allege that we are only helping the rich farmers and that it is not in accordance with the policies of our own Party, is not fair. They have also grumbled about the silly mistakes made by the Primary Production Department, one of which was to let out these lots of land. Only time will tell whether this is a silly mistake. Assuming the project is successful, we may then go on to smaller projects. But for the moment, in order to be successful we think that the project ought to be a substantial one.

    I am also surprised that the Primary Production Department is blamed for evicting small farmers from the catchment areas. The Members should have taken this point up when the Ministry of the Environment was being discussed in this House. It is the Ministry of the Environment that is in charge of pollution, and it is the Public Utilities Board that is building the reservoir in Kranji. The question is whether they want enough fresh water or enough pigs. So where the pig farms pollute some of the streams, we move them away from the streams. Hence, this pig farming project. But they have got to decide what they want. And sometimes the Government decides this for them.

    The Member for Toa Payoh grumbled about the increases in prices of Housing Board flats. I would not go into the details as to the reasons why the prices have gone up. He just wants to know why we did not spread this over a period of eight years so that the blow would not be so heavy. It is not easy to spread it over eight years. Because I do not know what will happen in eight years time! Perhaps the prices will have to go up again at the end of this year or next; I do not know, but I hope not. But to plan for so long and spread it over eight years is not a practical solution to the problem of rising prices.

Column: 646



3.15 p.m.

    The Member then said that because of the shortage of flats, unauthorised subletting should not be interfered with. The Member will remember that sometime last year or early this year, the Housing and Development Board announced that sublettings would be allowed. A three-room flat could be sublet, so could a four-room or five-room flat provided there are not many occupants already in the flat. I would suggest to the Member that he advises his constituents who have sublet their flats to regularise the position because it is no longer illegal to sublet Housing Board flats. And they can go further; they can even sublet Housing Board flats to non-citizens.

    The Member for Kim Keat wanted to know when legislation will be ready in respect of the Government statement made last September about foreigners owning land, and whether the delay is deliberate. I can assure him that it is not. What is the point of delaying this legislation? The Government gets no benefit from this. It is not simple legislation and we have had several drafts drawn up by the Attorney-General. The Member will be happy to know that a final draft is now before Government, and the Bill will be introduced at our next meeting of Parliament, after the Budget session. Meanwhile, the Registrar of Titles has received quite a few applications from foreigners to purchase land. These applications are being processed by a committee and replies will be given soon. Anyone who does not know whom to apply to, should apply to the Registrar of Titles.

    The Member for Bras Basah grumbled about land acquisition. He made some good points. One is on delays in issuing awards. There have been some delays of up to four years, which I agree is unfair. But I had on several occasions in the year before last directed those in charge to issue their awards as soon as possible and at the latest within a period of six months. But there are difficulties in cases where a large piece of land has been acquired and there are thousands of people on the land,

Column: 647
